Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling movement and survival of intercontinental songbird migrants crossing the Gulf of Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration: Approximately two-thirds of all songbird species that breed in eastern North America migrate to tropical areas for the winter, requiring most species to cross the Gulf of Mexico. Flights across the gulf are considered hazardous and may result in mass mortality. Atmospheric conditions over water, as well as characteristics of the birds themselves (e.g., age, physical condition), are likely important predictors of birds' migratory routes and survival. However, most knowledge about when, where and how small birds cross large water bodies and their survival remains speculative, because until now researchers have been unable to track individuals between the start and end points of over water flights. Anticipated changes in atmospheric structure and dynamics caused by climate change urgently require an understanding of how migrating birds interact with the atmosphere. This knowledge will provide insight to potential consequences of climate change on migratory songbirds, many of which are experiencing population declines. Knowledge of animal-atmosphere relationships is timely as wind energy development accelerates and coastal habitat alteration along migratory flyways continues. The interdisciplinary research team will combine modern radio telemetry and favorable geography to document migratory flights of songbirds across the gulf. By integrating field data, atmospheric data and computational simulations and analyses, the team will provide the first estimate of songbird survival during migration across open water. They also will study factors shaping birds' migratory routes and timing. The team will promote learning, excitement and appreciation for science, and animal migration in particular, to non-scientists through educational materials (e.g., animated migration trajectories in Google EarthÂ©). The team will disseminate findings to scientists, reserve managers and the general public via presentations, publications, a bilingual project website, and popular media. American and Latino undergraduate and graduate students and post-doctoral researchers will participate in each phase of research to acquire learning and skill-building opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For centuries scientists and non-scientists alike have been fascinated by bird migration. Accounts of migratory journeys across thousands of miles and inhospitable geographic features, like the Gulf of Mexico, have fueled our captivation with this phenomenon. We used automated radio tracking technology to study the behavior of migratory birds at stopover (resting and fueling) sites in coastal Alabama and the northern Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. By tracking three songbird species – red-eyed vireo, Swainson’s thrush, and wood thrush – we investigated how birds cross the Gulf of Mexico. We sought to understand the factors that determine birds’ decisions to depart across the Gulf, their likelihood of successfully arriving at the Yucatan Peninsula, the length of time to cross, and their recovery after arriving in Mexico.

In general, two factors determined whether a bird attempted to cross the Gulf of Mexico and if it was successful: energy (fat) reserves and wind conditions. Fat is the energy source birds use to migrate. Given the long distance and time required to cross and variability in the weather conditions encountered over water, it stands to reason that individuals with more fat are more likely to survive. Wind can make the crossing easier (supportive tail winds) or, conversely, more difficult (head winds). For example, strong head winds can cause birds to use up energy reserves more quickly, thereby increasing their likelihood of mortality. Wind also strongly influenced the length of time birds needed to cross, ranging from 13 hours with strong tailwinds to 35 hours under head winds. Accounts of large numbers of birds washing ashore and emaciated birds alighting on boats underscore the dangers associated with crossing the Gulf of Mexico. While our findings show that trans-Gulf flights might be very risky under less than ideal conditions, they also show that under favorable conditions (supportive winds and large fat reserves), crossing poses little risk.

Our research also highlighted important differences in how species cross the Gulf and whether they arrive in the Yucatan Peninsula. Overall, migration appears to be more demanding for the smaller red-eyed vireo than the larger Swainson's and Wood thrushes, resulting in differences in how the species migrate through the region. Thrushes fly over the Gulf much more frequently than vireos. If thrushes have large fat reserves, they can cross under a broad range of wind conditions. Swainson’s thrushes appear to avoid only the strongest headwinds when departing across the Gulf. Vireos, on the other hand, are restricted to crossing only when they have large fat loads and supportive weather conditions; hence, they have fewer opportunities for crossing. Most vireos departing the Alabama coast migrated around the Gulf or flew inland, away from the AL coast. Vireos presumably made inland flights in search of higher quality feeding areas where they could gain the extra energy needed to cross, as our coastal Alabama site is considered to offer insufficient food resources. Similar movement patterns (movements in seasonally inappropriate directions) of vireos were observed at stopover sites in the northern Yucatan Peninsula coast. As a consequence of these landscape movements and migratory flights around, rather than across, the Gulf, vireos took significantly longer move through the region, slowing down their migration.

This study improves our understanding of the strategies migrating songbirds use to cross the Gulf and provides valuable guidance for bird conservation. Many migratory bird species in North America are experiencing population declines. Our research highlights that wind and fat are important factors predicting whether a bird can successfully negotiate the Gulf of Mexico. While managers and conservationists cannot control wind conditions, they can protect and manage habitat to provide high quality refueling and resting opportunities for migratory birds in coastal areas and nearby inland areas around the Gulf of Mexico, thereby promoting their quick and safe migration. However, protection of natural habitat is at odds with urban development and other anthropogenic land-use changes common in coastal areas, creating a challenging task for conservationists. While protection of stopover habitat is the ideal target, efforts to promote feeding and resting opportunities, for example, through restoration, maintaining coastal vegetation in developed areas, and landscaping with native plants can also promote successful migration. We have created a short video targeted at non-scientific audiences to explain the challenges that migratory birds encounter in the Gulf of Mexico and explain ways we can promote their survival. We have promoted the video and our research findings on social media platforms and through presentations to local communities, conservation non-profits, natural resource managers and research centers in the Yucatan Peninsula where we completed this research. This video and others that show the methods that scientists use to track birds are available on our project webpage, along with site maps, photographs, and summaries of our research (http://gulfofmexicobirdmigration.net/).
